Award.AwardTitle: 2018 Workshop: Integrating Neurophotonics, Statistical Physics, and Control Theory for Advancing Neuroscience
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 50-person, two-day 2018 Workshop: "Integrating Neurophotonics, Statistical Physics, and Control Theory for Advancing Neuroscience" will identify research efforts that will be needed to close the gaps between the future potential and the current state-of-the-art in neurophotonic-sensing and modulation and big data as it relates to advancing our understanding of the rules of the functioning brain. The discussions among the multi-disciplinary participants will help to define the challenges and questions that should be addressed given the recent explosive growth in neurophotonics and big data technological capabilities for studying the brain. Inclusion of young scientists in the workshop will bring fresh perspective to the discussions and foster their career development through the interactions and networking. Specific major outcomes of the workshop will include the increased awareness of research, education, and technology transfer related to neurophotonics and big data; ideas enabling the transformation of research and STEM education; partnership opportunities among government, academia, industry, and the general public; and synergism for transformative activities in the application of neurophotonics and big data technology.

The Workshop will provide a forum for disseminating information and sharing ideas about the frontiers of neuro-sensing and modulation with light and the integration with statistical modeling, machine learning, and control theory. The workshop will contribute toward defining the important topics and questions to be addressed with future research, and will identify research directions and opportunities that, if pursued, can initiate new developments in neurotechnology and computational neuroscience / big data modeling that will lead to new break-through neuroscientific studies. The workshop will result in a comprehensive publishable document that will be widely distributed in the SPIE journal Neurophotonics. This workshop will be a two-day event on October 22-23, 2018, in Alexandria, Virginia. The workshop will focus on three themes: reviewing the frontiers of neuro-sensing and modulation with light and the intersection with big data methods; exploring the opportunities for neurophotonic methods to integrate with big data methods to significantly advance the impact on neuroscientific studies; and defining novel neuroscientific studies to guide the integration and advancement of these technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Workshop on "Integrating Neurophotonics, Statistical Physics, and Control Theory for Advancing Neuroscience" was held on October (21) 22-23, 2018 in Alexandria, VA. This 50-person two-day workshop provided a forum for disseminating information and sharing ideas about the frontiers of neuro-sensing and modulation with light and the integration with statistical modeling, machine learning, and control theory. The workshop focused on reviewing the frontiers of neuro-sensing and modulation with light and the intersection with control theory, machine learning, and statistical physics; Exploring the opportunities for neurophotonic methods to integrate with big data methods to significantly advance the impact on neuroscientific studies, and; Defining novel neuroscientific studies to guide the integration and advancement of these technologies. Organizers included Professors David Boas and Michael Hasslemo of Boston University, Chris Moore of Brown University, and Garrett Stanly of Georgia Institute of Technology. The workshop attendees explored the question of how the brain controls itself. It is known that control systems in the brain, such as the cortex, regulate complex behavior and memory. But the mechanisms by which brain circuits control behavior and memory are still largely unknown, despite decades of research using available experimental and theoretical techniques. The workshop resulted in in clearer understanding of research strategies that could combine instrument development, experimental investigation, and theoretical insight into significant advances in understanding brain function. The workshop transcended scientific disciplines of neuroscience, photonics, and dynamic control. Communication across these disciplinary boundaries was intended to cultivate collaboration leading to transformative impact on the grand challenge of understanding the brain.
